Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Harris, a long-time customer, unleashed his frustration. “How can I trust this offer? You people always call at the worst times!” His voice was sharp, demanding answers I was trained to provide, no matter how tough the objection. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “Never let a customer go without trying to win them back.” I took a deep breath, ready to explain every detail, to reassure him, to do my job.

But as I glanced at the clock, I realized Sunday service was starting. My church family would be singing, praying, and sharing in the warmth of community—something I’d missed for weeks. I felt a pang of guilt. As a Christian, I was expected to be present, to worship, to serve. Yet here I was, tethered to my headset, torn between my duty to my job and my longing to reconnect with my faith. My heart raced as I weighed the demands, caught between the voice on the line and the call in my soul.
